results.adx_keywords: Deaths (Obituaries);Movies;Actors and Actresses;Lollobrigida, Gina;Italy
results.title: Gina Lollobrigida, Movie Star and Sex Symbol, Is Dead at 95
results.abstract: She began her career in her native Italy and, although she achieved fame in America worked more often in Europe. She later had a second career as an artist and filmmaker.

media.caption: Gina Lollobrigida in the 1953 Italian-French comedy “Fanfan la Tulipe.” A year after it was released in the United States, she was on the cover of Time magazine.

results.adx_keywords: Floods;Rain;Landslides and Mudslides;California
results.byline: By Carly Olson, Ava Sasani, Luke Vander Ploeg and Julie Brown
results.title: A Break in California’s Storms Is in Sight. Here Are Regions to Watch.
results.abstract: Already soaked, the state is enduring yet another round of rain and snow.

media.caption: Work crews clearing a landslide on a highway near Grizzly Creek Redwoods State Park in Northern California.
media.copyright: Alexandra Hootnick for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: State Legislatures;Women and Girls;Dress Codes;Politics and Government;Coats and Jackets;Missouri
results.title: Missouri State Lawmakers Revise Their Dress Code for Women
results.abstract: The updated dress code requires female legislators and staff members in the State House of Representatives to wear a jacket, such as a blazer or a cardigan.

media.caption: Members of the Missouri House of Representatives in September. Lawmakers adopted a revised dress code for female legislators and staff members on Wednesday.

results.adx_keywords: Critics Choice Awards;Television;Movies;Blanchett, Cate;Bridges, Jeff;Coolidge, Jennifer;Coleman, Zendaya;Esposito, Giancarlo;Fraser, Brendan;Hauser, Paul Walter;Kwan, Daniel (Film Director);Monae, Janelle;Nash, Niecy;Odenkirk, Bob;Quan, Ke Huy;Ralph, Sheryl Lee;Scheinert, Daniel (Film Director);Seyfried, Amanda;Smart, Jean;White, Jeremy Allen;Winkler, Henry
results.title: Critics Choice Awards 2023: The Complete Winners List
results.abstract: “Everything Everywhere All at Once” wins the top prize, while Brendan Fraser takes best actor for “The Whale” and Cate Blanchett triumphs for “Tár.”

media.caption: Daniel Kwan, left, and Daniel Scheinert accepting the best directing award for “Everything Everywhere All at Once.”
media.copyright: Kevin Winter/Getty Images for Critics Choice

results.adx_keywords: Civil Rights Movement (1954-68);Civil Rights and Liberties;Monuments and Memorials (Structures);Art;King, Martin Luther Jr;King, Coretta Scott;Thomas, Hank Willis;MASS Design Group;Boston Common
results.title: In Boston, ‘The Embrace’ Honors Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s Legacy
results.abstract: The bronze sculpture, by the artist Hank Willis Thomas, symbolizes the hug Dr. King and Coretta Scott King shared after Dr. King won the 1964 Nobel Peace Prize.

results.adx_keywords: Labor and Jobs;Work-Life Balance;Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting
results.title: We Revisited People Who Left Their Jobs Last Year. Are They (Still) Happy?
results.abstract: Last summer we shared stories of people who were part of 2022’s surge in quitting. Months later, we asked them if they were still glad they switched gears.

media.caption: Ana del Rocío, a single mother who left her job in the nonprofit sector at the end of 2021, with her children, Inti and Tupac. She recently made the decision to seek public office in her home state of Oregon.
media.copyright: Leah Nash for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Hate Crimes;Asian-Americans;Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides;Assaults;Discrimination;Colleges and Universities;Davis, Billie R.;Indiana University;Bloomington (Ind)
results.title: Indiana University Student Stabbed in ‘Racially Motivated’ Attack, School Says
results.abstract: An 18-year-old student was stabbed several times in the head while she was riding a bus. A school official said the attack was a reminder “that anti-Asian hate is real.”

media.caption: An Indiana University student was stabbed in the head while riding a bus in Bloomington, Ind., in what officials said was a racially motivated attack.

results.adx_keywords: Airlines and Airplanes;Airports;Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters;Kennedy International Airport (Queens, NY);American Airlines;Delta Air Lines Inc;Federal Aviation Administration
results.byline: By Andy Newman and Livia Albeck-Ripka
results.title: ‘Delta 1943, Cancel Takeoff’: Wrong Turn Results in Near Miss at J.F.K.
results.abstract: An American Airlines plane crossed about 1,000 feet ahead of a Delta flight about to depart from Kennedy International Airport, officials said.

media.caption: The departing plane that had to halt its takeoff was a Boeing 737 operated by Delta Air Lines. It was en route to the Dominican Republic.

results.adx_keywords: Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides;Emergency Medical Treatment;Alcohol Abuse;Finley, Peggy;Cadigan, Peter;Springfield (Ill)
results.title: Two Illinois Paramedics Charged With Murder in Patient’s Death
results.abstract: “I am not playing with you now,” one of the paramedics told the patient, according to a video. The police said the emergency medical personnel “acted indifferently” in their response.

media.caption: A scene from body camera footage of paramedics responding to a man who was going through alcohol withdrawal, according to the police.

results.adx_keywords: Sex Crimes;Police;Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings;Women and Girls;Sexual Harassment;London (England);Great Britain
results.title: London Police Officer Admits to 49 Charges of Sexual Abuse, Including Rape
results.abstract: David Carrick, who worked for the Metropolitan Police, carried out “a relentless campaign” of violence over 17 years, prosecutors said, using his position of authority to manipulate victims.

media.caption: Officials at a news conference outside a London court on Monday after David Carrick, a former police officer, had pleaded guilty to sexual offenses against 12 women.
media.copyright: Jonathan Brady/Press Association, via Associated Press

results.adx_keywords: Water;Real Estate and Housing (Residential);Drought;Suits and Litigation (Civil);Conservation of Resources;Shortages;Sustainable Living;Arizona;Rio Verde (Ariz);Scottsdale (Ariz)
results.title: Skipped Showers, Paper Plates: An Arizona Suburb’s Water Is Cut Off
results.abstract: Hundreds of homes outside the boundaries of Scottsdale can no longer get water from the city, so their owners are living a worst-case scenario of drought in the West.

media.caption: A water hauler set up hoses to fill the tank for a home that is listed for sale in Rio Verde Foothills outside of Scottsdale, Ariz. Water prices have tripled for some residents of the unincorporated neighborhood.

results.adx_keywords: Organized Crime;Fugitives;Messina Denaro, Matteo;Italy;Sicily (Italy);Palermo (Italy)
results.byline: By Jason Horowitz and Gaia Pianigiani
results.title: Mafia Boss Arrested in Italy After Eluding Capture for 30 Years
results.abstract: Matteo Messina Denaro, who was sentenced in absentia for the 1992 murders of two prosecutors and other crimes, was apprehended at a Sicilian hospital.

results.adx_keywords: Deaths (Obituaries);Football (College);Heisman Trophy;Rose Bowl (Football Game);Football;Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy;White, Charles (1958-2023);University of Southern California;National Football League
results.title: Charles White, Heisman Winner With a Difficult Second Act, Dies at 64
results.abstract: A tough, bruising tailback, he set U.S.C.’s career rushing record. But he also dealt with drug and alcohol abuse and, later, dementia.

media.caption: Charles White of the University of Southern California in action against Michigan in the 1979 Rose Bowl. U.S.C. won, 17-10, and was named college football’s national champion in a poll of 35 coaches.

results.adx_keywords: Suits and Litigation (Civil);Facial Recognition Software;Discrimination;Security and Warning Systems;Madison Square Garden;MSG Network
results.title: Lawyers Barred by Madison Square Garden Found a Way Back In
results.abstract: MSG Entertainment resorted to facial recognition technology to kick out legal foes, but some have undermined the ban using a law passed to protect theater critics in 1941.

media.caption: Benjamin Noren, a lawyer with Davidoff Hutcher & Citron, is on a list of lawyers banned from Madison Square Garden.
media.copyright: Gili Benita for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Airlines and Airplanes;Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters;Deaths (Fatalities);Pilots;Yeti Airlines;Nepal
results.byline: By Bhadra Sharma and Mujib Mashal
results.title: 17 Years After Her Husband’s Crash in Nepal, a Pilot Met the Same Fate
results.abstract: Anju Khatiwada, who died on Sunday in a crash in Pokhara, Nepal, decided to become a pilot after her husband’s death in 2006. The family’s calamities are part of a deadly pattern of aviation disasters in Nepal.

media.caption: Rescuers on Monday recovering the body of a victim who died in a Yeti Airlines plane crash in Pokhara, Nepal, the day before. Seventy-two people were on the flight.

results.adx_keywords: Deaths (Fatalities);Traffic Accidents and Safety;Football (College);Smart, Kirby;University of Georgia
results.title: Georgia Player and Staff Member Killed in Crash After Celebratory Parade
results.abstract: Devin Willock, an offensive lineman, and Chandler LeCroy, a recruiting analyst, died after a vehicle driven by LeCroy crashed into power poles and trees.

media.caption: Devin Willock, wearing No. 77, during a game against Vanderbilt in October.
media.copyright: Dale Zanine/USA Today Sports, via Reuters

results.adx_keywords: Colleges and Universities;Artificial Intelligence;Computers and the Internet;Plagiarism;Grading of Students;Innovation;OpenAI Labs;Northern Michigan University;George Washington University
results.title: Alarmed by A.I. Chatbots, Universities Start Revamping How They Teach
results.abstract: With the rise of the popular new chatbot ChatGPT, colleges are restructuring some courses and taking preventive measures.

media.copyright: Steve Legato for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Cats;Pets;Animal Behavior;Animal Cognition;Research;your-feed-science;Animal Cognition (Journal)
results.title: Your Cat Might Not Be Ignoring You When You Speak
results.abstract: Cats have a reputation for being aloof, but a new study has found that their relationships with their owners may be stronger than we thought.

media.caption: Cats are often seen as aloof. But in a new study, they were not ignoring their owners, but instead “their reactions were very subtle,” the lead author of the study said.

results.adx_keywords: Floods;Weather;California;Santa Cruz County (Calif)
results.byline: By Carly Olson and Victoria Kim
results.title: In This California Mountain Town, Multiple Storms Deal Multiple Blows
results.abstract: The community of Felton in Santa Cruz County was still recovering from Tuesday’s rain when Saturday’s storm hit.

media.caption: In Felton Grove, Calif., Brandee Aragaki stood on her balcony, surveying the flooding in her neighborhood with her cat Coco Bear.
media.copyright: Mike Kai Chen for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Deaths (Obituaries);Religion-State Relations;Pledge of Allegiance;Decisions and Verdicts;Appeals Courts (US);Goodwin, Alfred T;Oregon
results.title: Alfred T. Goodwin, Judge in Pledge of Allegiance Case, Dies at 99
results.abstract: He ruled the pledge unconstitutional because the words “under God” violated the separation of church and state. The Supreme Court reversed the ruling.

media.caption: Alfred T. Goodwin, seated, after being sworn in as a U.S. District Court judge in Oregon in 1969. With him were his colleagues on the bench Judge Gus Solomon, left, and Judge Robert Belloni. Judge Goodwin was one of the longest-serving federal judges in U.S. history.
